revision.text:
The '''American Arbitration Association''' ('''AAA''') is a not-for-profit organization in the field of alternative [[dispute resolution]], providing services to individuals and organizations who wish to resolve conflicts out of court, and one of several [[arbitration]] organizations that administers arbitration proceedings. The AAA also administers [[mediation]] through '''Mediation.org''' and other forms of [[alternative dispute resolution]]. It is headquartered in [[New York City]], with regional offices in [[Atlanta]], [[Boston]], [[Charlotte, North Carolina|Charlotte]], [[Chicago]], [[Dallas]], [[Denver]], [[Detroit]], [[East Providence, Rhode Island]], [[Fresno]], [[Houston]], [[Los Angeles]], [[Miami]], [[Minneapolis]], [[New York City]], [[Philadelphia]], [[Phoenix, Arizona|Phoenix]], [[San Antonio]], [[San Diego]], [[San Francisco]], [[Seattle]], [[Somerset, New Jersey]] and [[Washington, DC]].
The '''International Centre for Dispute Resolution''' ('''ICDR'''), established in 1996 by the AAA, administers [[international arbitration]] proceedings initiated under the institution's rules. ICDR currently ({{As of|2018|lc=on}}) has offices in [[New York City]], [[Mexico City]], [[Singapore]], and [[Bahrain]].
The AAA provides services and online tools for Employer's General Counsel to create contracts of adhesion during all stages of hiring, employment, and post-employment favorable to those clients. They provide information demonstrating economic incentive for their Corporate clients to do so. They provide no information whatsoever for those to be brought under those contracts of adhesion. At the time of dispute they administer the selection of "neutral" arbitrators. They provide further information regarding the possibly legal destruction of documents and minimum retention of mandatory records according the "Sedona Principles" of eDiscovery.
== History == The AAA was founded in 1926 by the merger of the Arbitration Society of America and the Arbitration Foundation to provide dispute resolution and avoid [[Civil Court]] proceedings.<ref>[http://www.nndb.com/org/557/000117206/ Notable Names Database]- Retrieved 2012-03-08</ref>
Many [[contract]]s include an [[arbitration clause]] naming the AAA as the organization that will administer arbitration between the parties. The AAA does not itself arbitrate disputes, but provides administrative support to arbitrations before a single arbitrator or a panel of three arbitrators. The arbitrators are chosen in accordance with the parties' agreement or, if the parties do not agree otherwise, in accordance with the AAA rules. Under its rules, the AAA may appoint an arbitrator in some circumstances, for example, where the parties cannot agree on an arbitrator or a party fails to exercise its right to appoint an arbitrator.
The AAA role in the dispute resolution process is to administer cases, from filing to closing. The AAA provides administrative services in the U.S., as well as abroad through the ICDR. The AAA's and ICDR's administrative services include assisting in the appointment of mediators and arbitrators, setting hearings, conducting cases under the United Nations Commission on International Trade Law (UNCITRAL) Arbitration Rules, and providing users with information on dispute resolution options, including settlement through mediation. Ultimately, the AAA aims to move cases through arbitration or mediation in a fair and impartial manner until completion.
Additional AAA services include the design and development of alternative dispute resolution (ADR) systems for corporations, unions, government agencies, law firms, and the courts. The Association also provides elections services as well as education, training, and publications for those seeking an understanding of alternative dispute resolution.
In July 2009, the AAA stopped accepting consumer debt collection cases, after the [[National Arbitration Forum]] was forced to do so after questions arose about the fairness of its process.<ref>[https://www.npr.org/templates/transcript/transcript.php?storyId=106894662 Top Arbitration d Firms Exit Business] by [[Wade Goodwyn]] and Madeleine Brand. All Things Considered, National Public Radio. 22 July 2009.</ref>
In April 2013, the New York State Department of Financial Services hired the AAA to host mediation sessions between insurance companies and [[Hurricane Sandy]] victims.
The AAA has actively promoted the use of mediation around the world, including through its participation as a co-founder in 2007 and current board member of the Netherlands-based [[International Mediation Institute]].

{{update|date=March 2017}} The '''Arkansas Medical Cannabis Act''' (AMCA) is a proposed legislative act to appear on the 2016 general election ballot as an [[initiative]] in the U.S. state of [[Arkansas]]. According to a 2015 survey, 84% of Arkansas voters favored medical cannabis legalization, leading some to conclude passage of the 2016 act is likely.<ref name=Shortt/> The act has a provision to collect sales tax and apportions some of the revenue to subsidize low-income [[medical cannabis]] patients.<ref name=Dunnagan/>
==History== The wording of the initiative's title was approved by the Arkansas Attorney General in August, 2014, allowing the process of collecting signatures for the initiative to begin.<ref name=Lanning/> The sponsor of the act, Arkansans for Compassionate Care, submitted 117,469 petition signatures to the state authorities for verification in June, 2016.<ref name=AP20160621/> It was certified for the ballot on July 7.<ref name=AP20160707/>
==See also== *[[Cannabis in Arkansas]] *[[List of 2016 United States cannabis reform proposals]]

{{For|the freezing of economic resources relating to the enforcement of international sanctions or a nation's foreign policy|International sanctions|Economic sanctions|United States embargoes}} {{Judicial remedies}} '''Asset freezing''' is a legal process which prevents a [[defendant]] (usually an apparent fraudster){{sfn|McGowan|Crerar|2010|p=1}} to an [[lawsuit|action]] from dissipating their [[asset]]s from beyond the [[jurisdiction]] of a court so as to frustrate a potential [[Judgment (law)|judgment]]. It is widely recognised in other common law jurisdictions{{sfn|Collins|1989|p=271}} and such orders can be made to have world-wide effect. It is variously construed as part of a court's inherent jurisdiction to restrain [[abuse of process|breaches of its process]].
The jurisdiction arises in part from the [[Judicature Act 1873]], which provided that "A mandamus or an injunction may be granted or a receiver appointed by an interlocutory Order of the Court in all cases in which it shall appear to the Court to be just or convenient..." Relying on this, [[George Jessel (jurist)|Jessel MR]] in 1878 declared, "I have unlimited power to grant an injunction in any case where it would be right or just to do so..."<ref>{{cite court |litigants= Beddow v Beddow|vol= (1879) 9|reporter= Ch D|opinion= 89|pinpoint= 93|court= Ch D|date= 17 April 1878|url= https://books.google.ca/books?id=MBUtAQAAMAAJ&lpg=PA787&ots=r3JQyPD4hx&pg=PA786#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate= |quote=}}, quoted in {{cite court |litigants= Mareva Compania Naviera SA v. International Bulkcarriers SA|vol= [1975] 2|reporter= Lloyd's Rep|opinion= 509|pinpoint= |court= C.A.|date= 23 June 1975|url= http://www.uniset.ca/other/cs4/19801AER213.html|accessdate= |quote=}}</ref>
==Origins in ''Mareva''== The legal order itself is in the form of an [[injunction]], which in [[Commonwealth of Nations|Commonwealth]] jurisdictions is also known as a '''freezing order''', '''Mareva injunction''', '''Mareva order''' or '''Mareva regime''', after the case ''Mareva Compania Naviera SA v International Bulkcarriers SA'',<ref>{{cite court |litigants= Mareva Compania Naviera SA v. International Bulkcarriers SA|vol= [1975] 2|reporter= Lloyd's Rep|opinion= 509|pinpoint= |court= C.A.|date= 23 June 1975|url= http://www.uniset.ca/other/cs4/19801AER213.html|accessdate= |quote=}}, [1980] 1 All ER 213</ref> although the first recorded instance of such an order in English jurisprudence was ''Nippon Yusen Kaisha v Karageorgis'',<ref>{{cite court |litigants= Nippon Yusen Kaisha v Karageorgis|vol= [1975] 1|reporter= WLR|opinion= 1093|pinpoint= |court= C.A.|date= |url= |accessdate= |quote=}}, [1975] 3 All ER 282</ref> decided one month before ''Mareva''. The ''[[Civil Procedure Rules 1998]]'' now define a Mareva injunction as a "freezing order".
Asset freezing is not a security,<ref>{{cite AustLII|litigants=Jackson v Sterling Industries Ltd|link=|court=HCA|num=23|year=1987|pinpoint=|parallelcite=(1987) 162 CLR 612|date=11 June 1987|courtname=|juris=}}</ref> nor a means to pressure a judgment debtor,<ref>{{cite court |litigants= Camdex International Ltd v Bank of Zambia (No. 2)|vol= [1997] 1|reporter= WLR|opinion= 632|pinpoint= |court= |date= |url= |accessdate= |quote=}}</ref> nor is it a type of [[asset forfeiture]] since it does not confer upon anyone else a [[Ownership|proprietary interest]] in the defendant's assets.<ref>{{cite court |litigants= Cretanor Maritime Co Ltd v Irish Marine Management Ltd|vol= [1978] 1|reporter= WLR|opinion= 966|pinpoint= |court= |date= |url= |accessdate= |quote=}}</ref> However, some authorities have treated the Mareva injunction as an order to stop a judgment debtor from dissipating his assets so as to have the effect of frustrating judgment, rather than the more strenuous test of requiring an intent to abuse court procedure. An example of the former would be paying off a legitimate debt,<ref>{{cite court |litigants= Iraqi Ministry of Defence v Arcepey Shipping Co. S.A. ("The Angel Bell") |vol= [1981] 1|reporter= QB|opinion= 65|pinpoint= |court= |date= |url= |accessdate= |quote=}}</ref> whereas an example of the latter would be hiding the assets in overseas banks on receiving notice of the action.
A freezing order will usually only be made where the claimant can show that there was at least a good arguable case that they would succeed at trial and that the refusal of an injunction would involve a real risk that a judgment or award in their favour would remain unsatisfied.<ref>{{cite court |litigants= Ninemia Maritime Corporation v Trave Schiffahrtgesellschaft mbH und Co KG ("The Niedersachsen") |vol= [1983] 1|reporter= WLR|opinion= 1412|pinpoint= |court= |date= |url= |accessdate= |quote=}}</ref> It is recognised as being quite harsh on defendants because the order is often granted at the pre-trial stage in ''[[ex parte]]'' hearings, based on [[affidavit]] evidence alone.
A Mareva injunction is often combined with an [[Anton Piller order]] in these circumstances. This can be disastrous for a defendant as the cumulative effect of these orders can be to destroy the whole of a business' custom by freezing most of its assets and revealing important information to its competitors, and the two orders have been described by [[John Donaldson, Baron Donaldson of Lymington|Lord Donaldson]] as being the law's "nuclear weapons."<ref>''Bank Mellat v Nikpour'', [1985] FSR 87</ref><ref>{{cite web|author = Hefin Rees|title = Freezing Injunctions: A Nuclear Weapon For the Commercial Litigator|url = http://hefinrees.wordpress.com/2010/04/20/freezing-injunctions-weapon-for-commercial-litigator/|at = par. 2|date = 8 December 2009|publisher = Hefin Rees}}</ref>
===Application=== While it is not advisable to obtain such an order on purely strategic grounds,{{sfn|McGowan|Crerar|2010|p=1}} asset freezing has a persuasive effect on settlement negotiations.{{sfn|McGowan|Crerar|2010|pp=1{{endash}}2}} While a claimant obtaining an order can expect to face subsequent opposition in court from the defendant, the freezing order is generally considered to be the beginning of the end for the defendant,{{sfn|McGowan|Crerar|2010|p=4}} and negotiation and settlement avoid the return to court.{{sfn|McGowan|Crerar|2010|p=4}}
Current orders issued by the court do not generally call for a blanket freezing of assets, and they are currently worded in more nuanced terms according to the situation concerned.{{sfn|McGowan|Crerar|2010|p=4}}
The process is regarded as a high-stakes exercise for several reasons:{{sfn|McGowan|Crerar|2010|pp=5{{endash}}7}}
#The application is almost always made without notice, to prevent the fraudster defendant from spiriting away their assets before the freezing order is granted. Applicant’s counsel is therefore required to make full and frank disclosure of all material facts, and the applicable law, to the court. #As with most injunctions, the applicant must provide an undertaking to the court to compensate the defendant for any damage caused by the order. #A freezing order that is improperly or sloppily obtained, or one that is drafted too broadly or imprecisely, will cost the party, and its counsel, heavily in terms of credibility with the court.
===Extension to EU=== Similar provision can be found in the exercise of:
:* "arrestment on the dependence" under [[Scots law]]<ref>{{cite journal |last= Aird|first= Richard|year= 2002|title= The Scottish Arrestment and the English Freezing Order|url= https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/international-and-comparative-law-quarterly/article/the-scottish-arrestment-and-the-english-freezing-order1/134FA7F7D66E63BCF13DED28918D8243#|journal= [[International and Comparative Law Quarterly]]|publisher= Cambridge University Press|volume= 51|issue= 1|pages= 155{{endash}}169|issn = 0020-5893|jstor= 3663277|accessdate=9 September 2014}}{{Subscription or libraries}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last= Aird|first= Richard|year= 2010|title= The best-kept secret in commercial litigation|url= http://www.murraystable.com/assets/files/The%20best-kept%20secret%20in%20commercial%20litigation.pdf|journal= The Commercial Litigation Journal|publisher= |volume= 29|issue= |pages= 12{{endash}}15|issn= 1747-5317|accessdate= 9 September 2014|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20140910215724/http://www.murraystable.com/assets/files/The%20best-kept%20secret%20in%20commercial%20litigation.pdf|archive-date= 2014-09-10|dead-url= yes|df= }}</ref> and :* ''saisie conservatoire'' under [[French law]].<ref>{{cite journal |author= May Lee|year= 1982|title= Prejudgment Attachment in England: The Mareva Injunction|url= http://digitalcommons.lmu.edu/ilr/vol5/iss1/5|journal= Loyola of Los Angeles International and Comparative Law Review|publisher= [[Loyola Marymount University]]|volume= 5|issue= 1|page= 143}}</ref>
It has been extended to other members of the [[European Union]], by virtue of Article 9(2) of the ''[[Directive on the enforcement of intellectual property rights]]''.<ref>{{cite EU directive |serial= 2004/48/EC|year= 2004 |date= 29 April 2004 |description = on the enforcement of intellectual property rights |eurlextag = CELEX:32004L0048R(01)}}</ref> Since January 2017, a uniform [[European Account Preservation Order]] has been implemented in all EU member States (other than Denmark and the United Kingdom).<ref>{{cite web|title = The new European account preservation order - A nightmare for defendants and a litigant's dream?|url = http://www.allenovery.com/publications/en-gb/european-finance-litigation-review/eu-developments/Pages/The-new-European-account-preservation-order---A-nightmare-for-defendants-and-a-litigants-dream.aspx|publisher = [[Allen & Overy]]}}, discussing {{cite EU regulation |serial= 655/2014|date= 15 May 2014|description = establishing a European Account Preservation Order procedure to facilitate cross-border debt recovery in civil and commercial matters|eurlextag= CELEX:32014R0655}}</ref>
===United States=== ''Mareva'' was rejected by the [[Supreme Court of the United States]] in 1999 in ''Grupo Mexicano de Desarrollo, S.A. v. Alliance Bond Fund, Inc''.<ref>''Grupo Mexicano de Desarrollo, S.A. v. Alliance Bond Fund, Inc.'', {{ussc|527|308|1999}}</ref> For the majority, [[Justice Scalia]] held that, as such jurisdiction did not exist at the time of the passage of the [[Judiciary Act of 1789]], the federal courts had no authority to exercise it. In dissent, [[Justice Ginsburg]] asserted that the federal courts' exercise of its equity jurisdiction was never that static. While ''Grupo Mexicano'' is consistent with other Supreme Court jurisprudence in the matter of [[preliminary injunction]]s,<ref>{{cite journal |last= DiSarro|first= Anthony|year= 2011|title= Freeze Frame: The Supreme Court’s Reaffirmation of the Substantive Principles of Preliminary Injunctions |url= https://www.law.gonzaga.edu/law-review/files/2011/12/DiSarro.final_.pdf|journal= Gonzaga Law Review|publisher= [[Gonzaga University School of Law]]|volume= 47|issue= 1|pages= 51{{endash}}98|doi= |accessdate=4 September 2014}}</ref> there has been debate as to whether this decision should be reversed.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Capper |first=David |year=2005 |title=The Need for ''Mareva'' Injunctions Reconsidered |url=http://ir.lawnet.fordham.edu/flr/vol73/iss5/8/ |journal=[[Fordham Law Review]] |publisher= |volume=73 |issue=5 |pages=2161{{endash}}2181 |doi= |accessdate=4 September 2014 }}</ref>
At the state level, the [[New York Court of Appeals]] reached a similar conclusion to that of the Supreme Court in 2000, in ''Credit Agricole v. Rossiyskiy''.<ref>{{cite court |litigants= Credit Agricole Indosuez v. Rossiyskiy Kredit Bank|vol= 94|reporter= N.Y.2d|opinion= 541|pinpoint= |court= N.Y.|date= 2000|url= http://www.leagle.com/decision/200063594NY2d541_1584.xml/CREDIT%20AGRICOLE%20v.%20ROSSIYSKIY|accessdate= |quote=}}</ref>
In place of ''Mareva'', US civil jurisprudence relies more on [[Prejudgment writ of attachment|prejudgment writs of attachment]],<ref>available under [[Federal Rules of Civil Procedure|FRCP]] §{{frcp|64}}</ref> preliminary injunctions and [[temporary restraining order]]s,<ref>the latter two available under [[Federal Rules of Civil Procedure|FRCP]] §{{frcp|65}}</ref> which have a more limited scope of application.<ref>{{cite journal |last= Tamaruya|first= Masayuki|year= 2010|title= The Anglo-American Perspective on Freezing Injunctions|url= http://works.bepress.com/tamaruya/1/|journal= Civil Justice Quarterly|publisher= |volume= 29|issue= 3|pages= 350{{endash}}369|accessdate=7 September 2014}}</ref>
==Nature of order== Although it is mistakenly believed that a freezing injunction provides security over the defendant’s assets for a possible judgment, or secures a judgment already obtained, [[John Donaldson, Baron Donaldson of Lymington|Lord Donaldson MR]] explained in ''Polly Peck International Plc v Nadir'' that such is not the case:<ref>{{cite BAILII|litigants= Polly Peck International Plc v Nadir|link=|court=EWCA|division=Civ|year=1992|num=3|parallelcite= [1992] 4 All ER 769|date=19 March 1992}}</ref>
{{cquote| #So far as it lies in their power, the courts will not permit the course of justice to be frustrated by a defendant taking action, the purpose of which is to render nugatory or less effective any judgment or order which the plaintiff may thereafter obtain. #It is not the purpose of a ''Mareva'' injunction to prevent a defendant acting as he would have acted in the absence of a claim against him. Whilst a defendant who is a natural person can and should be enjoined from indulging in a spending spree undertaken with the intention of dissipating or reducing his assets before the day of judgment, he cannot be required to reduce his ordinary standard of living with a view to putting by sums to satisfy a judgment which may or may not be given in the future. Equally no defendant, whether a natural or a juridical person, can be enjoined in terms which will prevent him from carrying on his business in the ordinary way or from meeting his debts or other obligations as they come due prior to judgment being given in the action. #Justice requires that defendants be free to incur and discharge obligations in respect of professional advice and assistance in resisting the plaintiff's claims. #It is not the purpose of a ''Mareva'' injunction to render the plaintiff a secured creditor, although this may be the result if the defendant offers a third party guarantee or bond in order to avoid such an injunction being imposed. #The approach called for by the decision in ''American Cyanamid Co v Ethicon Ltd''<ref>{{cite BAILII|litigants=American Cyanamid Co v Ethicon Ltd|link=|court=UKHL|year=1975|num=1|parallelcite= [1975] AC 396|date=5 February 1975}}</ref> has, as such, no application to the grant or refusal of ''Mareva'' injunctions which proceed on principles which are quite different from those applicable to other interlocutory injunctions. }}
In 2007, [[Thomas Bingham, Baron Bingham of Cornhill|Lord Bingham]] declared:
{{cquote| Mareva (or freezing) injunctions were from the beginning, and continue to be, granted for an important but limited purpose: to prevent a defendant dissipating his assets with the intention or effect of frustrating enforcement of a prospective judgment. They are not a proprietary remedy. They are not granted to give a claimant advance security for his claim, although they may have that effect. They are not an end in themselves. They are a supplementary remedy, granted to protect the efficacy of court proceedings, domestic or foreign.<ref>{{cite BAILII|litigants= Fourie v. Le Roux & Ors|link=|court=UKHL|year=2007|num=1|para=2|parallelcite= [2007] 1 All ER 1087|date=24 January 2007}}</ref> }}
===Current scope===
In ''Group Seven'',<ref>{{cite BAILII|litigants= Group Seven Ltd v Allied Investment Corporation Ltd & Ors|link=|court=EWHC|division=Ch|year=2013|num=1509|para=63|date=6 June 2013}}</ref> [[Robert Hildyard (judge)|Hildyard J]] outlined the current scope of freezing orders that can be issued by the Court:
#It is designed to prevent injustice to a successful claimant by preserving assets and funds from being disposed of or dissipated before a judgment is satisfied. #"His assets" refers to "assets belonging to that person, not to assets belonging to another person" and without words clearly extending the scope of the phrase "his assets", assets owned beneficially by someone else will not be subject to the freezing order. #A freezing order is a precautionary measure taken urgently to protect the claimant against the risk of dissipation, disposal, reduction in value, or loss of assets pending a fuller examination as to what assets would in reality be available to the claimant for the purposes of enforcing a judgment. #If the words are ambiguous, or admit of a more restrictive interpretation, so that it is arguable whether or not the assets in question fall within their scope, the court is unlikely to treat a dealing with such assets as a contempt of court. #"Assets" also covers assets which are not in the legal ownership of the defendant but in respect of which the defendant "retains the power to direct how the assets should be dealt with." #The phrase "his assets" is extended to include also "assets held by a foreign trust or a [[Anstalt|Liechtenstein Anstalt]]<ref>the nature of which is discussed in {{cite journal |last= Glos|first= George E.|date= 1984|title= The Analysis of a Tax Haven: The Liechtenstein Anstalt|jstor= 40705579|journal= The International Lawyer|publisher= [[American Bar Association]]|volume= 18|issue= 4|pages= 929{{endash}}955|issn=0020-7810}}</ref> when the defendant retains beneficial ownership or effective control of the asset." #It is clear that those words in the standard form do not extend to assets of which the defendant remains the legal owner but holds for the benefit of someone else. #If it is desired and found appropriate to extend the scope of the injunction to assets held in trust (in the case of a façade or sham), additional wording must be included to make that clear, and the Court will only do this sparingly. #As to piercing or lifting the corporate veil, ownership and control of a company are not themselves sufficient to provide justification for that course, even when no unconnected third party is involved and it might be perceived that the interests of justice would be served by it. #Even where the circumstances are such as to justify the exceptional step of piercing or lifting the corporate veil, the effect is not to alter the beneficial ownership of the company's assets: it is simply to provide for such asset to be available in defined circumstances to the claimant.
In 2014, ''Lakatamia''<ref>{{cite BAILII|litigants= Lakatamia Shipping Company Ltd v Su & Ors|link=|court=EWCA|division=Civ|year=2014|num=636|parallelcite=|date=14 May 2014}}</ref> emphasized that the assets of a company wholly owned by a person subject to a freezing order are not automatically subject to the order. In that case, [[Colin Rimer|Rimer J]] noted:
{{cquote| The owner is of course able to control the destiny of the company's assets. But that does not make them ''his'' assets... First, [the order] is still only concerned with dispositions of assets belonging beneficially to the defendant, which these assets do not. Secondly, Mr Su has no authority to instruct the companies how to deal with their assets. All he has is the power, as an agent of the company, to procure the company to make dispositions of its assets. Such dispositions, when made, are made in consequence of decisions made by the organs of the company. They are not dispositions made by the company in compliance with instructions from Mr Su. That may seem to be a somewhat formal distinction. But it is a valid one: only the ''companies'' have authority to deal with and dispose of their assets.<ref>''Lakatamia'', par. 51</ref> }}
However, the person's shares in the company are subject to it, and any conduct by him (not in the course of ordinary business) that diminishes the value of those shares will infringe that order.<ref>''Lakatamia'', par. 43, 53</ref>
===''Chabra'' relief=== Subsequent jurisprudence<ref>{{cite court |litigants= T.S.B. Private Bank International SK v Chabra |vol= [1991] 1|reporter= WLR|opinion= 231|pinpoint= |court= |date= |url= |accessdate= |quote=}}</ref> has extended the reach of freezing orders to third parties against whom there is no substantive cause of action, but where there is good reason to suppose that their assets may in truth be the assets of the defendant against whom a cause of action is asserted. This type of order is known as ''Chabra'' relief, and has been described as possessing certain characteristics:<ref>''PJSC Vseukrainskyi Aktsionernyl Bank v Maksimov & Ors'', [http://www.7kbw.co.uk/media/uploaded_files/PJSC_Vseukrainskyi_Aktsionernyi_Bank_v_Maksimov_and_others.pdf [2013] EWHC 422 (Comm)] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140810161335/http://www.7kbw.co.uk/media/uploaded_files/PJSC_Vseukrainskyi_Aktsionernyi_Bank_v_Maksimov_and_others.pdf |date=2014-08-10 }}, mentioned at ''Lakatamia'', par. 32</ref>
#It may be exercised where there is good reason to suppose that assets held in the name of a defendant against whom the claimant asserts no cause of action (the NCAD) would be amenable to some process, ultimately enforceable by the courts, by which the assets would be available to satisfy a judgment against a defendant whom the claimant asserts to be liable upon his substantive claim (the CAD). #The test of "good reason to suppose" is that of a good arguable case. #The jurisdiction will be exercised where it is just and convenient to do so. #Assets will be treated as in truth the assets of the CAD if they are held as nominee or trustee for it as the [[Beneficial ownership|ultimate beneficial owner]]. #Substantial control by the CAD over the assets in the name of the NCAD is often a relevant consideration, but substantial control is not the test for the existence and exercise of the ''Chabra'' jurisdiction. It is relevant where there is a question of beneficial ownership, and where there is a real risk that assets may be dissipated in the absence of a freezing order.
===Available alternatives===
Depending on the circumstances, alternative types of orders may be more attractive to an applicant:<ref>{{cite web|author1= Shantanu Majumdar|author2= Christopher Buckley|title = Freezing Injunctions|url = http://www.radcliffechambers.com/media/Misc_Articles/Freezing_injunctions_-_revised_New.pdf|at= par. 30{{endash}}40|date = 17 May 2013|publisher = Radcliffe Chambers}}</ref>
#orders preserving property or securing a specified fund (where the balance of convenience favours making such an order), #a proprietary injunction (i.e., one that covers a specific asset or assets, as opposed to the defendant's assets in general), #the appointment of a receiver to hold assets of the defendant (where the injunction is insufficient on its own and where there is a measurable risk that a defendant will act in breach of the injunction), or #the appointment of a provisional liquidator (where the applicant is likely to obtain a winding-up order on the hearing of the petition).
A "third party debt order" (which consists of an interim freezing order and a final order requiring the third party to pay the debt to the judgment creditor) is available to secure payment of [[county court judgment]]s.<ref>{{cite web|title = Third party debt orders - the informal freezing injunction?|url = http://www.franciswilksandjones.co.uk/site/fwjsays/businessmoney/third_party_debt_orders.html|date = January 2011|publisher = Francis Wilks & Jones}}</ref>
==Extrajudicial application: "''Mareva'' by letter"== Informal ''[[de facto]]'' freezing may also be undertaken in most common law jurisdictions by a third-party guardian or assetholder, where he has been informed that those assets are imposed with a constructive trust in favour of someone other than the apparent owner. The freeze may be effected by issuing a letter to the asset holder or guardian in question, informing them of the true origin or beneficial ownership of the targeted funds or assets, and advising them of their potential accessory civil and possible criminal liability in the event of any transfer or disposal of the assets in question. Such devices may be employed in cases where a victim of fraud suspects that targeted funds or assets may be transferred to another location where it might be impractical to gain access to them. However, the use of this technique within the United States is not generally accepted.<ref>{{cite web|author = Martin S. Kenney|title = ''Mareva'' by Letter: Preserving Assets Extra-Judicially {{emdash}} Destroying a Bank's Defence of Good Faith by Exposing it to Actual Knowledge of Fraud. |url = http://www.martindale.com/international-law/article_Martin-Kenney-Co._258798.htm|publisher = martindale.com|date =27 November 2006 }}</ref>
==Further reading== * {{cite journal |last= Collins|first= Lawrence|authorlink= Lawrence Collins, Baron Collins of Mapesbury|year= 1989|title= The Territorial Reach of Mareva Injunctions|url= http://www.uniset.ca/lloydata/art/105LQRev262.html|journal= [[Law Quarterly Review]]|publisher= |volume= 105|issue= |pages= 262{{endash}}299|issn= 0023-933X|ref={{harvid|Collins|1989}}}} * {{cite journal |author= Harris Bor|year= 2014|title= Freezing orders in support of arbitration proceedings|url= |journal= Journal of International Banking and Financial Law|publisher= Butterworths|volume= 29|issue= 1|pages= 43{{endash}}45|issn=0269-2694}} * {{cite web |url= http://www.irwinlaw.com/titles/mareva-and-anton-piller-preservation-orders-canada|title= Mareva and Anton Piller Preservation Orders in Canada: A Practical Guide|last1= Crerar|first1= David|date= 2017|publisher= [[Irwin Law]]}} * {{cite web |url= http://www.blg.com/en/NewsAndPublications/Documents/publication_1603.pdf|title= Mareva Injunctions can stop Fraudsters cold|last1= McGowan|first1= D. Ross|last2= Crerar|first2= David|date= 2010|website= |publisher= [[Borden Ladner Gervais]]|ref=harv}}

Barker |formation = Virgin Islands Constitution Order, 1967 (Statutory) |last = |abolished = |succession = |deputy = |salary = |website = }}
The '''Attorney General of the British Virgin Islands''' is the principal legal adviser to the [[Government of the British Virgin Islands]].<ref>Virgin Islands Constitution Order 2007, article 58(2)</ref> Under the [[Constitution of the British Virgin Islands]] the Attorney General sits ''ex officio'' in both the [[House of Assembly of the British Virgin Islands]]<ref>Virgin Islands Constitution Order 2007, section 63(1)</ref> and in the [[Cabinet of the British Virgin Islands]],<ref>Virgin Islands Constitution Order 2007, article 47(1)</ref> but is not permitted to vote in either. The Attorney General also sits on the Committee for the Prerogative of Mercy<ref>Virgin Islands Constitution Order 2007, article 44(1)</ref> and on the National Security Council.<ref>Virgin Islands Constitution Order 2007, article 57(1)(d)</ref>
The office traces its origins back to the reintroduction of democracy in the British Virgin Islands pursuant to the [[British Virgin Islands general election, 1950|1950 general election]]. At that time the Legislative Council (as the House of Assembly was then known) had to look to the [[Attorney General of the Leeward Islands]] for support. This was regarded as unsatisfactory and following the [[British Virgin Islands general election, 1954|1954 general election]] Herman Besson was appointed to the title of Legal Assistant to the Legislative Council. In 1959 the title of the office was changed to Crown Attorney, and subsequent to the introduction of Ministerial Government following the [[British Virgin Islands general election, 1967|1967 general election]] the office was titled Attorney General.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://216.197.123.192/Portals/0/Forms/Election%20Information%20and%20Results%201950-2011.pdf |title=BVI election and information results 1950–2011 |publisher=BVI Deputy Governor's Office |pages=195–199 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140407063531/http://216.197.123.192/Portals/0/Forms/Election%20Information%20and%20Results%201950-2011.pdf |archivedate=7 April 2014 }}</ref>
The Attorney General is supported by two senior law officers: the Solicitor General (in relation to civil matters) and the Director of Public Prosecutions (in relation to criminal matters).
When appearing in court, by convention the Attorney General sits one row in from the row reserved for [[Queen's Counsel]].
The current Attorney General is Baba Aziz.<ref name=Aziz>{{cite web|url=http://bvinews.com/new/baba-aziz-appointed-attorney-general/|title=Baba Aziz appointed attorney general|publisher=BVI News|accessdate=15 January 2015}}</ref> Mr Aziz also formerly served as acting Attorney General for over a year between 24 June 2010 and 6 November 2011.
==Qualifications== Since 2007 in order to be qualified to be appointed as Attorney General a person must be eligible to be admitted as a lawyer in the British Virgin Islands, and must have not less than 10 years experience practising law.<ref>Virgin Islands Constitution Order 2007, article 95(5)</ref> However, this was not always the case, and various past Attorneys General were either not admitted in the British Virgin Islands and in some cases were not even eligible to be admitted in the British Virgin Islands.<ref>The longest ever serving Attorney General was [[Cherno Jallow]] QC, who was only admitted as a lawyer in Gambia, and was thereby ineligible for admission to practice as a lawyer in the British Virgin Islands.</ref>
By law, since 2007 no person may be appointed to the office of Attorney General unless he or she is a [[Belonger status|Belonger]] to the Virgin Islands unless, in the opinion of the Judicial and Legal Services Commission, there is no such person who is suitably qualified and able and willing to be so appointed.<ref>Virgin Islands Constitution Order 2007, article 95(6)</ref> In practice, every single Attorney General appointed since 2007 has been a non-Belonger, and only one Attorney General in the history of the British Virgin Islands was a belonger at the time they were appointed ([[Dancia Penn]]).<ref>Several Attorneys General settled in the British Virgin Islands and were naturalised after leaving office.</ref>
==List of Attorneys General of the British Virgin Islands== A total of 26 persons have been appointed to the office (including as Crown Attorney or Legal Assistant prior to 1967, and persons who were appointed as acting Attorney General), of whom 20 have been men and six have been women. Three have been [[Queen's Counsel]] (although two were appointed to the rank during office), and the remaining 23 have been from the [[junior barrister|Outer bar]] or [[solicitor]]s during their time as Attorney General.<ref>Two former Attorneys General were subsequently elevated to Queen's Counsel later in their careers: [[Joseph Archibald]], QC and Lewis Hunte, QC.</ref> The longest serving Attorney General to date has been [[Cherno Jallow]], who served just under eight years (including time as acting Attorney General).
For Attorneys General prior to 1954 see [[Attorney General of the Leeward Islands]]

{{Use Australian English|date=May 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2018}} '''Australian securities law''' relates to [[security (finance)|securities]] issued by [[corporation]]s as well as other securities, including [[debenture]]s, [[stock]]s and [[Bond (finance)|bonds]] issued by [[government]]s, and interests in [[managed investment scheme]]s.
Australian securities regulation rests on the principle that "financial markets cannot function effectively unless participants act with integrity and there is adequate disclosure to facilitate informed judgements".<ref>Commonwealth of Australia ''Financial System Inquiry Final Report'' (1997) p. 16.</ref> As a result, many of the regulatory rules governing dealings in securities are part of a broader framework that governs [[financial product]]s, [[financial services]] and [[financial markets]].
Mandatory disclosure and conduct regulation underlie much of Australia's securities regulation. [[False trading]], [[fraudulent dealing]], and [[insider trading]] are dealt with to prevent improper practices in connection with securities markets. A licensing system operates to ensure securities markets are fair, orderly and transparent. At the same time, securities law is also facilitative, allocating rights and duties in conjunction with general [[contract law]]. It also allows for a degree of [[Industry self-regulation|self-regulation]], by the operation for example of an independent [[securities exchange]].
Australian securities law has been substantially modernised in recent years. The core of these laws are found in the ''[[Corporations Act 2001|Corporations Act]]'' 2001 (Cth), which contains provisions governing [[takeover]]s, [[fundraising]], and financial products, services and markets.
== Legal and regulatory framework ==
The main body of [[substantive law]] about securities is found in the ''[[Corporations Act 2001|Corporations Act]]'' 2001 (Cth), as well as the regulations made under that Act. Whilst much of the law is derived from earlier regulation (especially the [[Boom and bust|bust]] in Australian mineral stocks of the late 1960s), the sections relating to securities regulation have been subject to recent amendment. The takeovers provisions were substantially re-written by the ''Corporation Law Economic Reform Program Act'' 1999. Changes to financial products, financial markets, and financial services were introduced by the ''Financial Services Reform Act'' 2001 (Cth), as a result of the ''Final Report of the Financial System Inquiry'', commonly referred to as "the Wallis report."<ref name=Wallis1997>{{cite book|last1=Financial System Inquiry|title=Final Report of the Financial System Inquiry|date=1997|location=Canberra, Australia|url=http://fsi.treasury.gov.au/content/FinalReport.asp|accessdate=13 July 2014}}</ref>
Elements of securities law are also found in the general law governing [[contract law|contracts]], [[trust law|trusts]], and [[torts]]. Securities regulation under the ''Corporations Act'' operates against the background of other Commonwealth legislation on [[Australian criminal law|criminal law]], [[Australian administrative law|administrative law]],<ref>''Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act'' 1977; ''Freedom of Information Act'' 1982; ''Privacy Act'' 1988.</ref> and [[statutory interpretation]].<ref>''Commonwealth Acts Interpretation Act'' 1901.</ref>
Administration of the legislation is the responsibility of the [[Treasurer of Australia|Commonwealth Treasurer]] and the [[Australian Securities and Investments Commission]] (ASIC), according to the ''[[Australian Securities and Investments Commission Act]]'' 2001 (Cth) and the ''Corporations Act'' 2001 (Cth). The market operator [[Australian Stock Exchange]] also has an important regulatory role to play.
The resolution of disputes is confided to the [[Federal Court of Australia|Federal Court]] and the Supreme Courts of the States and the Northern Territory, with other courts having some powers to apply the securities legislation.
== Definitions ==
A security is "a thing in action", a claim enforceable by legal proceedings rather than owning some tangible property. To effect regulation the legislation adopts various definitions of "security" and "financial product" that are used.
There is also no law which stipulates that no person in which authority is not given (anyone other the law enforcement or owners of an establishment) may restrict persons entering and leaving a premises.
== Licensing ==
Only the holder of a market licence may operate a financial market.<ref>[http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/legis/cth/consol_act/ca2001172/s791a.html ''Corporations Act'' 2001, s 791A].</ref>
=== Financial intermediaries ===
A person who carries on a financial services business in the jurisdiction must hold an Australian financial services licence.<ref>''Corporations Act'', s 911A(1).</ref>
== Market misconduct ==
Prevention of fraud and other forms of market misconduct has its foundation in the [[efficient-market hypothesis]].
General common law prohibitions against interfering with the free public market<ref>See for example ''R v de Berenger'' (1814) 3 Maule & S 67; 105 ER 536. See also "Notaras & Anor v Hugh & Ors" [2003] NSWSC 167.</ref> are strengthened by statutory prohibitions against various forms of market misconduct.<ref>''Corporations Act'' 2001 Part 7.10.</ref>
One set of statutory prohibitions is upon trading activity which manipulates market prices.<ref>Corporations Act, s 1041A.</ref> There are further prohibitions upon conduct that involves false trading or market rigging.<ref>[http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/legis/cth/consol_act/ca2001172/s1041b.html] ''Corporations Act'' 2001, s 1041B.</ref>

{{Infobox website | logo = | logo_size = frameless | logo_alt = | logo_caption = Copyright Evidence | screenshot = | screenshot_size = 250px | screenshot_alt = | collapsible = Yes | caption = <center>Screenshot of the top portion of the Conservapedia homepage on March 6, 2013</center> | url = {{URL|www.copyrightevidence.org}} | commercial = No | type = {{unbulleted list|[[Internet encyclopedia project]]|[[Wiki]]}} | registration = Optional (required to edit pages) | language = English | content_license = | owner = [[University of Glasgow]] | author = | alexa = | launch date = | current status = Active }}
'''Copyright Evidence''' is an English language wiki encyclopedia of empirical studies on copyright. It categorises legal studies on copyright so as to inform the public and policy development based on evidence. It was setup and run by CREATe at the [[University of Glasgow]].<ref name="copy">{{Cite web |url=https://www.copyrightevidence.org/evidence-wiki/index.php/Copyright_Evidence |title=Copyright Evidence |website=www.copyrightevidence.org |language=en |access-date=2018-09-29}}</ref>
== History == Copyright Evidence was established in 2014 by Theo Koutmeridis, Kris Erickson, and Martin Kretschmer, as a project undertaken by the CREATe research centre<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.copyrightevidence.org/evidence-wiki/index.php/Copyright_Evidence|title=Copyright Evidence|website=www.copyrightevidence.org|language=en|access-date=2018-10-22}}</ref>. The project aims to be a consolidated and interdisciplinary “central source” for evidence-based copyright studies<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.create.ac.uk/blog/2018/03/09/research-blog-series-copyright-evidence-wiki/|title=Research Blog Series: The Copyright Evidence Wiki|date=2018-03-09|work=CREATe|access-date=2018-10-22|language=en-GB}}</ref>, where users can examine findings and methodology transparently.
An editorial board was established in December 2017, which included the appointment of a sub-editor responsible for growing the existing base of studies<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.copyrightevidence.org/evidence-wiki/index.php/Copyright_Evidence|title=Copyright Evidence|website=www.copyrightevidence.org|language=en|access-date=2018-10-22}}</ref>.
== Methodology == Initial studies eligible for Copyright Evidence were identified using a snowball sampling methodology, beginning with a literature review by Watson, Zizzo and Fleming<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.create.ac.uk/publications/determinants-and-welfare-implications-of-unlawful-file-sharing-a-scoping-review/|title=Determinants and Welfare Implications of Unlawful File Sharing: A Scoping Review|date=2014-04-09|website=CREATe|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-10-22}}</ref>. Thereafter: 103 working papers and pre-prints were identified through the SSRN e-journal Intellectual Property: Empirical Studies (published between November 1996 and July 2015)<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/sample_issues/1649836_CMBO.html|title=Intellectual Property: Empirical Studies eJournal :: SSRN|website=papers.ssrn.com|access-date=2018-10-22}}</ref>; 81 studies via literature reviews by Handke<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://sites.nationalacademies.org/cs/groups/pgasite/documents/webpage/pga_063399.pdf|title=Economic Effects of Copyright: The Empirical Evidence So Far. The Committee on the Impact of Copyright Policy on Innovation in the Digital Era|last=Handke|first=C|date=22 October 2018|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>, Kretschmer<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kretschmer|first=Martin|date=2012|title=Does Copyright Law Matter? An Empirical Analysis of Creators’ Earnings|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.2139/ssrn.2063735|journal=SSRN Electronic Journal|doi=10.2139/ssrn.2063735|issn=1556-5068}}</ref>, and Kheria<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kheria|first=S|date=2013|title=Copyright and Digital Art Practice: The ‘Schizophrenic’Position of the Digital Artist|url=|journal=Leonardo Electronic Almanac|volume=19(4)|pages=|via=}}</ref>; and 50 governmental reports as proposed by CREATe doctoral candidates.
Ongoing growth of Copyright Evidence is achieved by search-based identifications. A literature review, conducted by the University of Illinois<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.create.ac.uk/blog/2018/03/09/research-blog-series-copyright-evidence-wiki/|title=Research Blog Series: The Copyright Evidence Wiki|date=2018-03-09|work=CREATe|access-date=2018-10-22|language=en-GB}}</ref>, confirmed the veracity and comprehensiveness of Copyright Evidence in late-2018.
== Format == Copyright Evidence catalogues all “empirical studies on copyright in an attempt to inform policy interventions based on rigorous evidence”<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.copyrightevidence.org/evidence-wiki/images/a/a4/WikiManual.pdf|title=A Guide to using the Copyright Evidence Wiki|last=CREATe|first=|date=2016|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>. Permitted studies may also include multi-disciplinary elements, and do not need to be strictly legal in nature. Copyright Evidence is currently closed for unauthenticated user submissions, with relevant studies being identified and coded by a community of CREATe research assistants.
Each entry details the main findings of the relevant study, a description of the data involved, and relevant policy considerations. Studies are also categorised (amongst other factors) by country, JEL code, and research method. Iconographic indicators are used to identify the relevant industry, fundamental issues, and policy areas.
== Findings == Copyright Evidence currently holds details of over 600 evidence-based studies on copyright, and acts as a dynamic literature review platform which is open to text and data mining.
Mining and visualisation tools were explored during the 2016 EUHackathon<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.kl.nl/en/news/euhackathon-2016-visualising-copyright-evidence/|title=EUHackathon 2016: visualising copyright evidence {{!}} Kennisland|work=Kennisland|access-date=2018-10-22|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://copyrightliteracy.org/2016/08/24/eu-hackathon-visualizing-copyright-evidence/|title=EU Hackathon: Visualizing Copyright Evidence|date=2016-08-24|work=UK Copyright Literacy|access-date=2018-10-22|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://codeweek.eu/view/11774/2016-euhackahton-visualising-copyright-evidence|title=Europe Code Week|website=codeweek.eu|language=en|access-date=2018-10-22}}</ref>, which identified certain clusters of cross-referencing between key related studies. Governmental reports, for example, tend to cross-reference other governmental reports, but less so academic evidence on copyright<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.create.ac.uk/blog/2018/03/09/research-blog-series-copyright-evidence-wiki/|title=Research Blog Series: The Copyright Evidence Wiki|date=2018-03-09|work=CREATe|access-date=2018-10-22|language=en-GB}}</ref>.
Copyright Evidence visualisations provide summary statistics on the landscape of the indexed studies<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.copyrightevidence.org/evidence-wiki/index.php/Example_Visualisations|title=Example Visualisations - Copyright Evidence|website=www.copyrightevidence.org|language=en|access-date=2018-10-22}}</ref>. These demonstrate how the majority of copyright studies focus on: (a) the sound recording and music publishing industry; (b) understanding consumption/use (e.g. determinants of unlawful behaviour, user-generated content, social media), and; (c) enforcement (quantifying infringement, criminal sanctions, intermediary liability, graduated response, litigation & court data, commercial VS non-commercial, education & awareness)<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.epip2015.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/EPIP-Koutmeridis-WikiLaunch.pdf|title=CopyrightEvidence.org|last=Erickson, K., Koutmeridis, T., Kretschmer, M., and McHugh, A.|first=|date=2015|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Citation|last=EPIP 2015|title=EPIP 10th Annual Conference: CREATe Copyright Evidence WiKi|date=2015-09-22|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=14DxSm2E5VU|access-date=2018-10-22}}</ref>.
Copyright Evidence is cited as a resource to support the use of empirical evidence in informing copyright policy<ref>{{Cite book|title=Reconciling Copyright with Cumulative Creativity: The Third Paradigm|last=Frosio|first=G|publisher=Edward Elgar Publishing Limited|year=2018|isbn=|location=Cheltenham|pages=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.core-econ.org/the-economic-effects-of-copyright/|title=The economic effects of copyright - CORE|date=2017-03-20|work=CORE|access-date=2018-10-22|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>CopyrightAgency (2015) Submission to Productivity Commission Intellectual Property Arrangements Issues Paper (November 2015) at p13</ref><ref>European Commission (2012) Evaluation of the application of Regulation 386/2012 Final Report at p36</ref>.

{{Infobox high court |court_name=Court of Appeals in Cases of Capture |established=January 15, 1780 |dissolved=June 21, 1788 |country=[[United States]] |location=Various Locations within the [[United States]] |type=Selection by the [[Confederation Congress]] |authority=Statute Enacted by the [[Confederation Congress]] |appeals=None Available |Available |positions=3}} The former '''Court of Appeals in Cases of Capture''', established by resolution of the [[Congress of the Confederation]] on January 15, 1780,[http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(jc01617)): Cont'l Cong., Journal and Records from Jan. 15, 1780, in 16 ''Journals'' 61-64.] was the first [[United States federal court system|federal court]] in the [[United States of America]]. ==Origin== [[File:American_privateers_Edgar_S_Maclay.gif|thumb|During the [[American Revolution]], the [[United States]] issued [[letters of marque|letters of marque and reprisal]] authorizing private vessels, known as [[privateers]], to capture enemy ships and cargo as [[prize (law)|prizes]].]] The idea for the Court originated from requests sent by [[General of the Armies|General]] [[George Washington]] during the [[American Revolutionary War|American Revolution]] to [[President of the Continental Congress|President of Congress]] [[John Hancock]],[https://archive.org/stream/writingsgeorgew57washgoog#page/n237/mode/2up George Washington, Letter to the President of Congress dated Nov. 11, 1775, in 3 ''The Writings'' 213-14.][https://archive.org/stream/writingsgeorgew57washgoog#page/n281/mode/2up George Washington, Letter to the President of Congress dated Dec. 4, 1775, in 3 ''The Writings'' 257-58.] but initially resulted in only the establishment of committees within [[Second Continental Congress|Congress]] to exercise such [[jurisdiction]].[http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(jc00350)): Cont'l Cong., Journal and Records from Nov. 17, 1775, in 3 ''Journals'' 357-58.][http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(jc00354)): Cont'l Cong., Journal and Records from Nov. 23, 1775, in 3 ''Journals'' 364-65.][http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(jc00355)): Cont'l Cong., Journal and Records from Nov. 24, 1775, in 3 ''Journals'' 368-69.][http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(jc00356)): Cont'l Cong., Journal and Records from Nov. 25, 1775, in 3 ''Journals'' 371-75.] Upon learning of this deviation from his earlier requests, Washington sent another request to Hancock again asking that Congress establish the Court,[https://archive.org/stream/writingsgeorgew57washgoog#page/n299/mode/2up George Washington, Letter to the President of Congress dated Dec. 14, 1775, in 3 ''The Writings'' 274.][http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(jc00381)): Cont'l Cong., Journal and Records from Dec. 26, 1775, in 3 ''Journals'' 457.] but Congress did not fulfill his request until almost four years later. ==Authority for establishment== Although specific express power to establish the Court was granted to [[Congress of the Confederation|Congress]] in the [[Articles of Confederation]],[http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/ampage?collId=llsl&fileName=001/llsl001.db&recNum=129 Articles of Confederation art. IX, § 1.] the Articles of Confederation were not yet fully [[Ratification|ratified]] by all [[Thirteen Colonies|thirteen of the original states]] when [[Second Continental Congress|Congress]] established the Court on January 15, 1780.[[Maryland]] did not [[ratification|ratify]] until February 2, 1781; see discussion of ratification by the states in [[Articles of Confederation]]. However, the [[Supreme Court of the United States|U.S. Supreme Court]] ruled that Congress nonetheless had inherent power at that time to establish the Court.[[Penhallow v. Doane's Administrators|''Penhallow v. Doane's Adm'rs'', 3 U.S. 54 passim (1795)]] (holding throughout a [[seriatim|seriatim opinion]] that [[Congress of the Confederation|Congress]] had inherent power to establish the Court of Appeals in Cases of Capture prior to [[ratification]] of the [[Articles of Confederation]]). ==Duration== The Court operated from shortly after its founding in 1780[[Bancroft Davis|J.C. Bancroft Davis]], ''Federal Courts'', [http://google.com/books?id=FmYUAAAAYAAJ&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false 131 U.S.] app. at xxviii, xxix, and xxxv-xlix (see cases numbered 21, 38, 40, 45, 49, 50, 53, 56, 65 through 68, and 72 adjudicated or otherwise disposed of in 1780). through its final cases in 1787.[[Bancroft Davis|J.C. Bancroft Davis]], ''Federal Courts'', [http://google.com/books?id=FmYUAAAAYAAJ&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false 131 U.S.] app. at xxviii, xxix, and xxxv-xlix (see cases numbered 87, 89, 103, and 109 adjudicated or otherwise disposed of in 1787). It officially ceased to exist following [[ratification]] of the [[U.S. Constitution]] in 1789See discussion of ratification by the states in [[United States Constitution]]. that transferred federal judicial power to the newly created [[Supreme Court of the United States|U.S. Supreme Court]] and such other inferior (i.e., lower) [[Federal judiciary of the United States|federal courts]] as Congress may establish.[http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/ampage?collId=llsl&fileName=001/llsl001.db&recNum=140 U.S. Const. art. III, § 1]; see also discussion of Section 1 in [[Article Three of the United States Constitution]].[[Penhallow v. Doane's Administrators|''Penhallow v. Doane's Adm'rs'', 3 U.S. 54 (1795)]], 86 (opinion of [[William Paterson (judge)|Paterson]], J.) ("The existence of the Court of Appeals [in Cases of Capture] terminated with the old government [of the United States of America] . . . ."). ==Jurisdiction== Beginning with [[Massachusetts]] on November 1, 1775, several of the [[Thirteen Colonies|American colonies]] (and, later, states) established [[prize court]]s to exercise [[original jurisdiction]] over all cases (or [[Libel (admiralty law)|libels]]) of [[prize (law)|captures (or prizes)]] consisting of enemy ships and cargo.[[Bancroft Davis|J.C. Bancroft Davis]], ''Federal Courts'', in [http://google.com/books?id=FmYUAAAAYAAJ&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false 131 U.S.] app. at xx-xxii. Establishment of such courts was recommended by Congress on November 25. 1775. On November 25, 1775, [[Second Continental Congress|Congress]] also asserted federal [[Appellate court|appellate]] [[jurisdiction]] over such cases. Following repeated scheduling difficulties when Congress attempted to hear the first appeal,[http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(jc00551)): Cont'l Cong., Journal and Records from Aug. 5, 1776, in 5 ''Journals'' 631.][http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(jc00557)): Cont'l Cong., Journal and Records from Aug. 12, 1776, in 5 ''Journals'' 647.][http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(jc00568)): Cont'l Cong., Journal and Records from Aug. 26, 1776, in 5 ''Journals'' 702.] Congress initially assigned this jurisdiction to various special committees,[http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(jc00580)): Cont'l Cong., Journal and Records from Sept. 9, 1776, in 5 ''Journals'' 747.][http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(jc00597)): Cont'l Cong., Journal and Records from Sept. 30, 1776, in 5 ''Journals'' 835.][http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(jc0068)): Cont'l Cong., Journal and Records from Oct. 17, 1776, in 6 ''Journals'' 884-85.][http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(jc00624)): Cont'l Cong., Journal and Records from Nov. 7, 1776, in 6 ''Journals'' 931-32.][http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(jc00641)): Cont'l Cong., Journal and Records from Nov. 27, 1776, in 6 ''Journals'' 985-86.][http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(jc00665)): Cont'l Cong., Journal and Records from Dec. 31, 1776, in 6 ''Journals'' 1060.][http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(jc0078)): Cont'l Cong., Journal and Records from Jan. 4, 1777, in 7 ''Journals'' 13.][http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(jc00714)): Cont'l Cong., Journal and Records from Jan. 11, 1777, in 7 ''Journals'' 30.] followed by a standing committee on Jan. 30, 1777.[http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(jc00729)): Cont'l Cong., Journal and Records from Jan. 30, 1777, in 7 ''Journals'' 75.][[Bancroft Davis|J.C. Bancroft Davis]], ''Federal Courts'', in [http://google.com/books?id=FmYUAAAAYAAJ&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false 131 U.S.] app. at xxiii-xxv and xxxv-xlix (see cases numbered 1 through 64). Later, on January 15, 1780, Congress established the Court of Appeals in Cases of Capture to exercise this jurisdiction as a [[Supreme court|court of last resort]].[http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(jc01617)): Cont'l Cong., Journal and Records from Jan. 15, 1780, in 16 ''Journals'' 61.] On May 24, 1780, Congress transferred all remaining appeals pending before committees to the Court and specified that all future appeals were to be filed directly with the Court.[http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(jc01715)): Cont'l Cong., Journal and Records from May 24, 1780, in 17 ''Journals'' 457-59.] On June 27, 1786, the Court's jurisdiction was again expanded to include [[New trial|rehearings and new trials]] in certain cases wherever justice so required.[http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(jc030128)): Cont'l Cong., Journal and Records from June 27, 1786, in 30 ''Journals'' 355-56.] Special jurisdiction was also conferred upon the Court on February 11, 1782 for a capture adjudicated by a prize court in [[Connecticut]][http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(jc02230)): Cont'l Cong., Journal and Records from Feb. 11, 1782, in 22 ''Journals'' 72.] and on July 24, 1786 for a capture of the sloop Chester.[http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(jc030146)): Cont'l Cong., Journal and Records from July 24, 1786, in 30 ''Journals'' 423-24.] ==Times and locations of sessions== The first session of the Court was required to be held in [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]] at the earliest opportunity. Subsequent sessions were to be held at other times and locations in the United States as deemed conducive to the public good, but no farther east than [[Hartford, Connecticut]], and no farther south than [[Williamsburg, Virginia]]. [[Congress of the Confederation|Congress]] later specified the time and location for some sessions of the Court, including specific sessions to be held at Hartford, Connecticut; Philadelphia, Pennsylvania; [[Richmond, Virginia]]; and [[New York City|New York, New York]].[http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(jc02469)): Cont'l Cong., Journal and Records from Jan. 29, 1783, in 24 ''Journals'' 98.] ==Procedure== The primary means of initiating an [[appeal]] to the Court required a party to first demand an appeal in the [[trial court]] within five days after definitive sentence and then file an appeal in and give adequate security to the Court within forty days after demanding an appeal in the trial court.[http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(jc01715)): Cont'l Cong., Journal and Records from May 24, 1780, in 17 ''Journals'' 459.] On Sept. 5, 1781, an extension of time for appeal was granted in the case of a capture decided in favor of Patrick Mahon against Roger Kean.[http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(jc02136)): Cont'l Cong., Journal and Records from Sept. 5, 1781, in 21 ''Journals'' 935-36.] Additionally, some appeals filed with Congress and referred to committees were subsequently transferred to the Court.[[Bancroft Davis|J.C. Bancroft Davis]], ''Federal Courts'', in [http://google.com/books?id=FmYUAAAAYAAJ&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false 131 U.S.] app. at xxxiv-xlix (see cases numbered 3, 18, 21, 30, 38, 40, 45, 49, 50, 53, and 56). [[Jury trial|Trial by jury]] was considered inconsistent with the [[Public international law|usage of nations]], and, therefore, was not authorized in the Court. However, trial by jury was authorized in some of the state [[prize court]]s, where Congress initially recommended it, only to later recommend against it.[http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(jc01617)): Cont'l Cong., Journal and Records from Jan. 15, 1780, in 16 ''Journals'' 62.] In any case before the Court that involved a capture suspected of being collusive, the Court was required to demand sufficient proof to the contrary from the captor and, if the captor failed to meet this burden, the Court was required to award the prize to the state where the original trial was held.[http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(jc022131)): Cont'l Cong., Journal and Records from July 17, 1782, in 22 ''Journals'' 392-93.] ==Judges== The Court was composed of three judges, but a [[quorum]] only required the presence of two judges. All judges serving on the Court were first required to take the following [[oath of office]] administered before the [[President of the Continental Congress|President of Congress]]:
You do swear or affirm, [that you will well, faithfully and impartially execute the office of one of the judges of the Court of Appeals in Cases of Capture, according to the best of your skill and judgment. So help you God.][http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(jc01715)): Cont'l Cong., Journal and Records from May 24, 1780, in 17 ''Journals'' 458.]
Initially, the judges received annual salaries for their services with reimbursement for expenses,[http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(jc0187)): Cont'l Cong., Journal and Records from Sept. 13, 1780, in 18 ''Journals'' at 822.] but their compensation was later changed to provide for only fixed daily rates, including time spent traveling on official business of the Court.[http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(jc0292)): Cont'l Cong., Journal and Records from July 1, 1785, in 29 ''Journals'' 493.][http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(jc03029)): Cont'l Cong., Journal and Records from Feb. 9, 1786, in 30 ''Journals'' 60-61.][http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(jc030101)): Cont'l Cong., Journal and Records from May 19, 1786, in 30 ''Journals'' 291.] The following individuals were elected by [[Continental Congress|Congress]] to serve as judges on the Court: * [[William Paca]] (elected Jan. 22, 1780;[http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(jc01623)): Cont'l Cong., Journal and Records from Jan. 22, 1780, in 16 ''Journals'' 79.] accepted Feb. 8, 1780;[http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(jc01638)): Cont'l Cong., Journal and Records from Feb. 9, 1780, in 16 ''Journals'' 143.] resigned November 21, 1782[http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(jc02368)): Cont'l Cong., Journal and Records from Nov. 21, 1782, in 23 ''Journals'' 746.]). * [[Titus Hosmer]] (elected Jan. 22, 1780; accepted April 12, 1780;[http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(jc016107)): Cont'l Cong., Journal and Records from May 4, 1780, in 16 ''Journals'' 411.] died in office Aug. 4, 1780[[Bancroft Davis|J.C. Bancroft Davis]], ''Federal Courts'', in [http://google.com/books?id=FmYUAAAAYAAJ&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false 131 U.S.] app. at xxvi.). * [[George Wythe]] (elected Jan. 22, 1780; declined to serve Feb. 21, 1780[http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(jc01666)): Cont'l Cong., Journal and Records from March 13, 1780, in 16 ''Journals'' 254.]). * [[Cyrus Griffin]] (elected April 28, 1780;[http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(jc016103)): Cont'l Cong., Journal and Records from April 28, 1780, in 16 ''Journals'' 397.] accepted May 4, 1780). * [[George Read (U.S. statesman)|George Read]] (elected Dec. 5, 1782;[http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(jc02376)): Cont'l Cong., Journal and Records from Dec. 5, 1782, in 23 ''Journals'' 765.] accepted Dec. 10, 1782[http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(jc02385)): Cont'l Cong., Journal and Records from Dec. 19, 1782, in 23 ''Journals'' 821.]). * [[John Lowell]] (elected Dec. 5, 1782; accepted Feb. 12, 1783[http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(jc02498)): Cont'l Cong., Journal and Records from March 17, 1783, in 24 ''Journals'' 186.]). As judges on the Court, George Read had seniority over John Lowell based on the results of an election in Congress held on Dec. 13, 1782.[http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(jc02381)): Cont'l Cong., Journal and Records from Dec. 13, 1782, in 23 ''Journals'' 797.] ==Cases== Surviving records show that a total of fifty-six cases were lodged with and adjudicated or otherwise disposed of by the Court, including eleven cases that were transferred from committees within [[Continental Congress|Congress]] to the Court.[[Bancroft Davis|J.C. Bancroft Davis]], ''Federal Courts'', in [http://google.com/books?id=FmYUAAAAYAAJ&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false 131 U.S.] app. at xxxiv-xlix (see cases numbered 3, 18, 21, 30, 38, 40, 45, 49, 50, 53, 56, and 65 through 109). Although the Court did not generally issue formal written opinions of its decisions, opinions of the Court were nonetheless published in the following cases:[[Bancroft Davis|J.C. Bancroft Davis]], ''Federal Courts'', in [http://google.com/books?id=FmYUAAAAYAAJ&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false 131 U.S.] app. at xxxv.[https://books.google.com/books?id=Nis3AAAAIAAJ&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false 2 Dall.] *1-41 (using star pagination from 1st ed.). * ''The Resolution'', {{Ussc|2|1|Ct. App. in Cases of Capture 1781|Dall.|2}}. * ''The Resolution'', {{Ussc|2|19|Ct. App. in Cases of Capture 1781|Dall.|2}} (rehearing). * ''The Erstern'', {{Ussc|2|34|Ct. App. in Cases of Capture 1782|Dall.|2}}. * ''The Gloucester'', {{Ussc|2|36|Ct. App. in Cases of Capture 1782|Dall.|2}}. * ''The Squirrel'', [https://books.google.com/books?id=Nis3AAAAIAAJ&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false 2 Dall.] *40 (Ct. App. in Cases of Capture 1783) (authorized sale of ship to avoid deterioration; proceeds from sale remained subject to adjudication) (using star pagination from 1st ed.). * ''The Speedwell'', [https://books.google.com/books?id=Nis3AAAAIAAJ&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false 2 Dall.] *40 (Ct. App. in Cases of Capture 1784) (reversed condemnation because capture occurred after preliminary articles of peace) (using star pagination from 1st ed.). * ''Luke v. Hulbert'', [https://books.google.com/books?id=Nis3AAAAIAAJ&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false 2 Dall.] *41 (Ct. App. in Cases of Capture 1787) (dismissed) (using star pagination from 1st ed.). * ''The Experiment v. The Chester'', [https://books.google.com/books?id=Nis3AAAAIAAJ&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false 2 Dall.] *41 (Ct. App. in Cases of Capture 1787) (dismissed) (using star pagination from 1st ed.). Custody of records from the Court was first transferred to the [[Supreme Court of the United States|U.S. Supreme Court]].[http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/ampage?collId=llsl&fileName=001/llsl001.db&recNum=402 Act of May 8, 1792, ch. 36, § 12, 1 Stat. 275, 279] (transferring custody of records from the Court of Appeals in Cases of Capture to the [[Supreme Court of the United States|U.S. Supreme Court]]). However, the [[National Archives and Records Administration|National Archives]] now maintains custody of the records.[https://research.archives.gov/id/299840 Act of June 19, 1934, Pub. L. No. 73-432, 48 Stat. 1122] (establishing the [[National Archives and Records Administration|National Archives]]).[https://research.archives.gov/description/1518851 ''Revolutionary War Prize Cases'' (available at the National Archives as Microform Publication M162).] ==See also== *[[Federal judiciary of the United States]] *[[Prize court]] *[[Prize (law)]] *[[Letter of marque]] *[[Privateer]] *[[Second Continental Congress]] *[[American Revolutionary War]] ==Endnotes== {{Reflist}} ==Sources== * [[Bancroft Davis|J.C. Bancroft Davis]], ''Federal Courts Prior to the Adoption of the Constitution'', in [http://google.com/books?id=FmYUAAAAYAAJ&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false 131 U.S.] app. at xix-lxiii (New York and Albany, Banks & Brothers 1889). * [https://archive.org/details/writingsgeorgew57washgoog George Washington, Letters, in 3 ''The Writings of George Washington, 1775-1776,'' (Worthington Chauncey Ford, New York and London, G. P. Putnam's Sons 1889).] * [http://memory.loc.gov/ammem/amlaw/lwjc.html Cont'l Cong., Journal and Records, in ''Journals of the Continental Congress, 1774-1789'' (Library of Cong. eds., 1904-1937).] ==Further reading== * Henry J. Bourguignon, ''The First Federal Court: The Federal Appellate Prize Court of the American Revolution, 1775-1787'', in 122 Memoirs of the American Philosophical Society (1977). * [https://research.archives.gov/description/1518851 ''The Revolutionary War Prize Cases: Records of the Court of Appeal in Cases of Capture, 1776-1787'' (available at the National Archives as Microform Publication M162).] {{USAConfGov}} {{George Washington|state=collapsed}} [[Category:Defunct United States courts]] [[Category:Prize warfare]] [[Category:1780 establishments in the United States]] [[Category:1788 disestablishments in the United States]] [[Category:Continental Congress]] [[Category:History of the United States (1776–89)]]

They are published by [[Sweet & Maxwell]].<ref>James Willing. Willing's Press Guide. Willing Service. 1998. Volume 1. Page 372.</ref> Publication began in 1979.<ref>Enid Mona Campbell, Poh York Lee, Joycey G. Tooher. Legal Research: Materials and Methods. Fourth Edition. LBC Information Services. 1996. [https://books.google.com/books?id=XlZ2xo-mk8AC&pg=PA34#v=onepage&q&f=false Page 34].</ref> As of 2008, they were published six times each year.<ref>Advanced Criminal Litigation in Practice. For the purpose of [[case citation|citation]], their name may be abbreviated to "Cr App R (S)".<ref>Advanced Criminal Litigation in Practice. Oxford University Press. 2008. [https://books.google.com/books?id=zj1jR-aOi30C&lpg=PA3&pg=PA3#v=onepage&q&f=false Page 3].</ref>
